This is it. The countdown has begun. Want to know if Widener is right for you? Hear from current students about what it's really like to learn, live, play and get involved here. Find out why YOU should become part of the Pride.

Gifts from generous alumni and friends strengthen Widener and help shape the university's future. When you give today, you put our students on the inside track to success.

Giving to Widener makes a difference to all our students by improving our facilities, enhancing our programs, and increasing our ability to provide financial assistance to students in need.  To learn more about opportunities for giving, visit
When is an IRA distribution not an IRA distribution?
When you make a qualifying gift to a charitable organization like Widener!

Donors above 70 1/2 are able to make gifts directly from their IRA that bypass the required minimum distribution. Charitable distribution gifts can be a tax-wise, and easy, way to make the kind of impact at Widener that you never thought possible.
Learn where other donors are giving >>
Widener's mission is supported by gifts from generous alumni, parents, and friends.  We are proud to list them on our 2018-2019 Honor Roll of donors.
Part of the Widener experience is teaching our students about the importance of philanthropy.
Learn how we're helping our students help each other >>
The Office of Development is here to help you identify the Widener giving opportunities that best suit your goals, passions and priorities.
You have the opportunity to leave a legacy for the next generation of students by making a contribution to the Class Gift. All Class Gift donations support the
, which provides financial support to students in need. With 95% of Widener students receiving financial aid, your gift will make a difference.
All gifts to the Class Gift fund will be matched
by an anonymous donor at a 1:1 ratio. That means you have the opportunity to double your impact, just by showing your support!
To show our appreciation for your support, members of the senior class who give will receive the following benefits for making a gift at a certain level, including all preceding incentives:
*Suggested giving levels. Undergradutes who give at an amount equivalent to their graduation year will also receive a Class Gift shirt.

Fast starts. Rapid advancement. Lasting success.
Each year Widener students field full-time job offers from their co-op employers - in many cases months ahead of graduation.
Mapping the Future of Robotics Engineering
Robotics engineering students are gaining an early introduction to the cutting-edge and diverse robotics industry through co-ops that offer hands-on, real-world experience.
From Campus to the Campaign Trail
Numerous Widener students and alumni have carved out successful careers in government and politics, working both behind the scenes and in elected positions.
Your path to a rewarding future starts here. Uncover a personal, powerful program that meets your learning goals.
Our two law schools, located in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, and Wilmington, Delaware, offer unique, rigorous approaches to legal education.
No matter your age or where you are in life, Widener can help you advance in your career.
Our points of pride not only designate us as a top tier university, they also demonstrate the resources and connections we offer that lead students to successful, rewarding careers.
Within 6 months of graduation, 94% of Class of 2019 was employed, in grad school, or in military/other service, according to survey data.
Small class sizes allow faculty to make you the priority.
You'll be welcomed into a community that hails from 49 states and 22 countries.
From soccer and volleyball to rugby and track, there are plenty of varsity sports to enjoy at Widener.
of Full-time Grad Students Receive Aid
The average undergraduate academic scholarship amounts to $105,000 over 4 years.
Payscale ranks Widener in the top 18% nationwide with an alumni mid-career salary of $101,100.
Named a best value college in Greater Philadelphia by Niche.com
of universities and liberal arts institutions nationwide.
87% Live on Campus Their First Year
Before long, our campus will feel like your second home.
Widener was awarded a 2018 Higher Education Excellence in Diversity Award from
With 80  clubs, you'll find ways to get involved, make invaluable connections, and pursue your interests.
President Julie Wollman welcomes faculty, staff and students to the start of the spring semester.
International Scholarship Recipient Finds Home at Widener
Nigerian student Chiamaka Oduah is the university's first recipient of the #YouAreWelcomeHere scholarship for international students.
Nursing Students Excel at the 2019 SNAP Convention

From student awards, faculty presentations and meaningful resolutions, students in the Widener University Student Nurses' Association demonstrated their commitment to nursing excellence at an annual state-wide students nurses’ association conference.
Live Online Chat with Current Undergraduate Students
Engineering Mini-Camp for High School Girls
Whether you're studying on the quad or exploring cultural treasures in nearby Philadelphia, you'll discover a vibrant second home at Widener.
Clinical rotations taught Kaylee how to interact with patients and handle real-world scenarios.
Our proximity to Philadelphia provided Kaylee with access to world-class medical facilities.
Our flexible nursing program meant Kaylee could pursue nursing and play lacrosse.
In the finance lab, DeShawn managed an investment fund using the same technology found on Wall Street.
Student Government Association representative and president of Black Men United, DeShawn was a campus leader.
Deshawn developed relationships with industry-connected professors and received valuable professional advice.
Biomedical Engineering Major, Biomedical Engineering Master's
Small classes allowed for one-on-one interactions with professors, helping Luis develop an interest in neuroscience.
An international student, Luis was far from home, but he found a welcoming community.
Through the 4 1 engineering program, Luis earned his degrees in less time, jumpstarting his career.
Multiple internships prepared Danielle for a job with the Philadelphia Eagles.
In Widener’s state-of-the-art broadcasting studio, Danielle gained experience with industry-standard equipment.
Her professor's strong industry connections opened the door for Danielle.
